CO2 absorption of  terrestrial IR occurs at 15um wavelenth and follows "Beers Law" - college chemistry basics. The absorption is maximized, 99.9%, in under 10m from the earth's surface at CO2 concentration of just 200ppm or less.  Increasing CO2 does not increase absorption further, so there is no increase in IR energy absorption from the earth's surface with CO2 doubling. This is basic college chemistry and physics of the issue. The truth is that CO2 increase does not further add to the greenhouse effect  than it already does. There is a great series of short 4min lectures on YouTube about the details by Michel van Biezen.

I see no doubt that climate change is real and very little doubt that it is associated human activity. As I set my thermostat, it dawned on me that I don't know if the obvious contribution of building heat has been considered, and how it compares to the effect of greenhouse gases like CO2. The contribution of building heat is obviously huge (think of the forests of skyscrapers in large cities), and its steep contribution would correspond to the turn of the 19th century (as would the greenhouse effect). Building heat contribution is obviously NOT an essentially thermodynamically--neutral phenomenon like air conditioning. The need to heat indoors in winter exists in huge swaths of landed areas, mostly in the northern hemisphere. Insulation slows the rate of heat dissipation and reduces the total amount of heat needed, but it does not eliminate heat loss entirely. I'm not an expert and may have missed coverage of this aspect of climate change, but nowhere have I heard of any scientific investigation comparing heat added by greenhouse gas effects vs heat added by the sum of all indoor space heating - a heretofore glaring oversight. Even if we manage to eliminate all artificial discharge of CO2 into the atmosphere, would we really slow down climate change? By how much? Would it be better to invest money in better insulation systems?

The Little Ice Age (LIA) was a period of regional cooling, particularly pronounced in the North Atlantic region.[2] It was not a true ice age of global extent.[3] The term was introduced into scientific literature by Fran√ßois E. Matthes in 1939.[4] The period has been conventionally defined as extending from the 16th to the 19th centuries,[5][6][7] but some experts prefer an alternative timespan from about 1300[8] to about 1850.

The Medieval Warm Period (MWP), also known as the Medieval Climate Optimum or the Medieval Climatic Anomaly, was a time of warm climate in the North Atlantic region that lasted from c.‚Äâ950 to c.‚Äâ1250.

At the same time as some scientists were suggesting we might be facing another ice age, a greater number published contradicting studies. Their papers showed that the growing amount of greenhouse gasses that humans were putting into the atmosphere would cause much greater warming ‚Äì warming that would exert a much greater influence on global temperature than any possible natural or human-caused cooling effects.

By 1980 the predictions about ice ages had ceased, due to the overwhelming evidence contained in an increasing number of reports that warned of global warming. Unfortunately, the small number of predictions of an ice age appeared to be much more interesting than those of global warming, so it was those sensational 'Ice Age' stories in the press that so many people tend to remember.  The fact is that around 1970 there were 6 times as many scientists predicting a warming rather than a cooling planet. Today, with 30+years more data to analyse, we've reached a clear scientific consensus: over 99% of scientists agree.  There is as much disagreement about anthropogenic global warming as there is about evolution or plate tectonics - ie zero.  It‚Äôs happening.

Also, we're well below the normal CO2 levels that has nurtured life for hundreds of millions of years. 1000 - 4000ppm is normal. We're freaking out because we went from 280 to 413ppm. Several eras including the Phanerozoic had 5000 - 6000ppm and there's zero evidence of the oceans boiling off or any other runaway greenhouse catastrophes. A few degrees warmer, no ice caps, more life and vegetation, and a more stable climate across the entire globe.

Burning all the fossil fuels available wouldn't even bring us close to that, because so much of the stored carbon is financially impractical to extract.

Also, global sea level averages have only changed by millimeters a year in the modern era. Local changes are very normal. People don't understand basic planetary physics and climate change activists take advantage of that to take your attention from real issues like wars, poverty, social decline, etc. Please don't fall for this, do the hard research that google won't tell you.

"Catastrophic?" Historical geology shows that a series of heating and cooling events have occurred over the past 2.6 million years, ever since Earth's most recent Ice-Age started. We're going to cross 2 deg C between 2035-2043 and as we do feedback cycles involving permafrost melting, wild fires, polar ice melt, Greenland, beetles killing drought stressed pine trees etc are going to cause the planet to depart from its current "equilibrium" point to a new one on an *exponential* time scale. I can not be the only person in the world who has studied control theory and statistical inference... I don't underhand how these people can be so blind. What most climate models are only now starting to take into account is the process of climate change acceleration due to feedback loops.  One example is fire and melting.  It gets hotter.  So you have more forest fires (CO2) and permafrost melt (Methane).  That release make it hotter.  So you have even more forest fires and permafrost melting.  Which makes it even hotter.  And so on.  The process of climate change acceleration due to these feedback loops means it will not take as long to get to 3C as many believe right now.

3 degrees centigrade? This is just scaremongering. The world may not even experience that increase. It depends on how much CO2 is emitted. The IPCC has various scenarios for different temperature increases depending on the amount of CO2 emitted, the worst being the notorious 'RCP 8.5' which alarmists frequently use. The IPCC now admits that RCP 8.5 is now very unlikely to happen. CO2 levels may never rise sufficiently to get an increase of 3 degrees. Remember that the rise in temperature is a constant (equilibrium climate sensitivity, ECS) for a doubling of CO2 & if we assume this constant is say 2 degrees per doubling, with CO2  now at 420 parts per million it would have to rise to 840 parts per million to raise the temperature of the planet by just 2 degrees, (not three!). Scientists don't even agree on what the actual value of the ECS is & different models use different values & furthermore each value is the mean of a spread of values! All very imprecise as climate science is. This video is crystal ball gazing of the worst kind & is displayed to generate fear & as such is pure evil. It's not science. It's pure propaganda. @Paul Scott 
I can understand your criticism against climate change activism, and there are many flaws in the concept as its presented in the media, but please don't peddle misinformation. I have operated a  greenhouse in the past, I work in botanical research, and what you've written here is unscientific poppycock.

1. Supplementing CO2 doesn't increase plant growth unless the other required inputs are also increased simultaneously, especially: Mg+2, H2O, and light. CO2 + fertilizer are limiting reactants, only involved in the carbon-fixation component of photosynthesis and are incapable of increasing photolysis which is a function of light + H2O. In a commercial greenhouse, increasing soil H2O exacerbates losses by increasing rot and algae; increasing H2O only works well in hydroponic systems which don't exist in natural environments. Mg+2 is increased by artificial input of fertilizer which also doesn't exist in nature. Light is increased by artificial lighting usually supplied by metal hallide or high-pressure sodium elements which also doesn't exist in nature. Photosynthesis will not increase if only some of the inputs for C-fixation is increased; photolysis has to increase simultaneously because its product, 2H, is also a reactant in C-fixation.

2. Deserts are deserts due to lack of water. Increasing CO2 to increase C-fixation will not increase photosynthesis because water is still missing for photolysis. 

3. Increasing ambient CO2 increases aquatic carbonic acid, making all bodies of water more acidic which kills the primary food supply of most fish: corals.

june 22 to July 31, 1952

The summer of 1952 was (at the time) the hottest summer ever recorded across the eastern half of the United States.

Climate Division Temperature Percentile Rankings for June-July 1952

Climate Division Temperature Percentile Rankings: June-July 1952

The summer of 1952 was (at the time) the hottest summer ever recorded across the eastern half of the United States. Well above-normal temperatures during most of June became exceptionally hot for the last week of the month as surface high pressure developed across Florida and upper level high pressure centered itself overhead.  All-time high temperatures were recorded in a number of locations including Wilmington, NC where the temperature hit 104 degrees on June 27th, 1952, a record that still stands today.  New Bern, NC reached 106 degrees on July 22, 1952, setting not just their all-time record high temperature but also their all-time highest daily average temperature of 93.5 degrees. (The morning low was a sticky 81 degrees)

High temperatures were only in the 80s and lower 90s for the first half of July, but the heat wave came roaring back on July 18th.  In Florence and Columbia, SC 100+ degree temperatures occurred on 8 out of 11 days from July 20th through July 30th.  New Bern, NC recorded its all-time record high temperature of 106 on July 22th, and Hickory, NC set its all-time record high of 105 on July 29th.  At least six deaths were blamed on the heat, and agricultural losses to the tobacco crop in North Carolina alone may have approached $10 million.  The impact this heat wave had on the people living here is magnified by the fact that very few homes had air conditioning in 1952.

Other all-time record highs established during this event include 103 in Southport, NC; 104 in Winston-Salem, NC; 106 in Marion, NC; 108 in Cheraw, SC; and 109 in Bamberg, SC.  Charlotte, NC's morning low of 79 degrees on June 27th is still the warmest low temperature on record for the Queen City.

One way to at least temporarily adapt to a Wet-Bulb Temperature of 35 degrees C. is nocturnalism: humans would go from being active during the day to being active at night. This is because at night, the temperature is cooler than it is at day. Nocturnalism would allow people to avoid the deadly Wet-Bulb Temperatures by literally sleeping during such temperatures. However, without air conditioning, people would have to sleep underground, where it is cooler even at daytime. Actually, many desert animals (such as jerboas) sleep in burrows during the daytime hours specifically to stay out of the daytime desert heat.

Im from Montreal Canada and I remember as a kid we used to get super cold winter that goes up to -37 celcius and is usually around -28 celcius. We used to have a decent spring (a bit over 2 month) and now spring barely last a month at the expense of winter lasting for a longer period of time. Someday spring would just become a myth of the past with winter temperatures lasting 5-6 month, summer lasting around 3 month and autumn lasting a bit less then 3 month.

No, it's not possible to avoid +3C.  There is at least a decade of heating already built into the biosphere due to the lag between the evulsion of a bolus of CO2 and the full manifestation of the heating it produces.  While CO2 is up 50% since pre-industrial, methane (much more potent a GHG) is up nearly 300%.  CO2 and CH4 are both now freely emitting from melting permafrost...that is a source we have NO control over.  Once triggered, it's self-amplifying.  Algal blooms on the surface of ice sheets has darkened hundreds of thousands of hectares of ice in the Arctic, speeding the melt.  This is not yet represented in the models.
So, not only is it not possible to avoid +3C., it is almost certain that we won't be able to avoid 6 or even 8C.  That is extinction level habitat collapse.

I stopped eating animal products after reading the 2018 Oxford study on agricultural practices. The study - which collected and analyzed data from 40 000 farms in 119 countries - clearly states that even the most sustainable animal foods requires more land use, more resources and cause more greenhouse gas emissions than the worst of plant foods. The animal agriculture sector cause 83 % of the agricultural greenhouse gas emissions even though globally it only provides 18 % of calories. The opportuniy to cut ones footprint by leaving out the animal foods is huge! 

To me it was such an "aha moment" that I completely changed my diet and haven't looked back. I really want my nieces to grow up in a beautiful and habitable world.

*If you're aware of that, then you must be aware of the younger drias too*
Yes, I know about the Younger Dryas.

*... and how the temperature change increases the closer we are to start and end of inter glacial periods.*
That doesn't apply to where we are now, nor to the Younger Dryas.

*Moreover, ..."*
Moreover??? You've yet to make a single point.

*... we only have accurate temperature data for 150-200 years...*
The word "accurate" is always vague. The real issue is always "how accurate". Prior to the "thermometer era", the temperature reconstructions have less accuracy, as they rely on indirect proxies rather than direct temperature readings. Even during the thermometer era, the accuracies of global average temperature calculations decrease the farther back in time you go due to more sparse global thermometer coverage.

So we do have a global average temperature record prior to the late19th century... but it's just that they're less accurate than the temps we've measured since then (and even the late 19th century is less accurate than, say, the last 70 years... and certainly the last 45 years when global satellite measurements became possible.).

I hope that you aren't suggesting that we don't have temperature data prior to the last 19th century, squeezed between your examples the temperatures from thousands of years ago.

*... and the earth has been gradually warming up even before those years.*
Temperatures during the Holocene have been mostly flat - certainly during the last 8,000 years or so - and if anything might have been slightly cooling. The point is, the warming coming out of the last glacial maximum ("ice age") ended a LONG time ago, and isn't relevant to what we're seeing today.

*While industrialisation did play a role, attributing majority of change to CO2 is just being ignorant.*
You just declared that generations worth of humanity's PhD research climate scientists, and the overwhelming majority of currently active climate scientists, are "ignorant". You did this one post after implying that Milankovitch cycles might somehow be relevant to the current warming... a mistake demonstrating no understanding of orders of magnitude and how to consider data, a mistake showing that you lack the elementary competence of a typical freshman physics student. Do you have any idea how ridiculous that makes you look?

Do tell, what was your most advanced science class? Was that in high school, or college? Let's put some perspective on your competence to declare that the entire scientific world is "ignorant".

*Even during the times of ancient civilizations, the temperatures were increasing and cities being submerged, you're totally overlooking that to fit your point.*
I'm overlooking it because it's irrelevant. Isolated and anecdotal incidents aren't scientifically relevant - we don't need them when we have actual data on the matter in question. Of course, if they represented some kind of conflict with the scientific findings, then that would be something interesting to explore... but I'm aware of no such conflicts.

Rest assured, the scientists aren't "overlooking" anything that's genuinely relevant to the science. Whenever it happens that *YOU* think something is relevant that the scientists aren't concerned with, then the issue is metaphysically certain to be thanks to YOUR ignorance in evaluating what's relevant, and definitely is not THEIR willful oversight in order to somehow argue whatever your delusions are about the scientist's imagined "agenda".

@Kryptonarie 63 In a stunning development today, the community of global climate scientists announced that the problem of global warming is actually one of global cooling, overturning decades of previously accepted, peer-reviewed science. Apparently, a few weeks ago, a graduate student at the University of California discovered, through the mistaken introduction of an erroneous "minus" sign into all climate data sets back in 1882, that all data suggesting growing concentrations of greenhouse gases, rising temperatures, increasing sea level, disappearing ice, and other changes were actually completely backward.

"We're very embarrassed," said Dr. Melissa Tonnennsen, a climate scientist with NASA, "but we must admit that sign errors do occasionally occur. We normally discover them, but this one slipped by us for over a century. The climate is still changing -- we got that right -- it's just that everything is going in the other direction."

When the error in each data set is corrected, the global average temperature can be seen clearly to be declining (Figure 1), sea level is dropping, not rising, and the amount of ice in the Arctic is really growing rapidly, not decreasing (Figure 2). Even the iconic image of rising carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, measured for half a century at Mauna Loa, Hawaii, turns out to be wrong -- affected by the same error. Figure 3 shows that in fact, atmospheric carbon dioxide is dropping, not rising. "We now realize," said Dr. Tonnennsen, "that burning fossil fuels takes carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere, it doesn't put it in." 

This discovery was not touched on by the global media as it does not suit the politics or dogma around this issue. Science gets thing wrong more often than not. We certainly need to reduce our dependence on fossil as an ice age would be something we need to take rather more seriously.

You're wrong, and the following information comes directly right from NASA/climate. 
One of the ‚Äúsmoking guns‚Äù that tells us the Sun is not causing global warming comes from looking at the amount of solar energy that hits the top of the atmosphere. Since 1978, scientists have been tracking this using sensors on satellites, which tell us that there has been no upward trend in the amount of solar energy reaching our planet.

A second smoking gun is that if the Sun were responsible for global warming, we would expect to see warming throughout all layers of the atmosphere, from the surface to the upper atmosphere (stratosphere). But what we actually see is warming at the surface and cooling in the stratosphere. This is consistent with the warming being caused by a buildup of heat-trapping gases (CO¬≤ for example) near Earth's surface, and not by the Sun getting ‚Äúhotter.‚Äù

The biggest idea I am trying to express is tunneling aqueducts from the coast, in this case the west coast of the USA inland to feed combination geothermal power and sea water desalination plants.  The idea seems to be so big that no one has considered it possible but I believe it is not only possible but it is necessary. For over a century the fossil water contained in aquifers has been pumped out to feed agriculture, industry and municipal water needs. The natural water cycle cant refill fossil water deposits that were filled 10,000 years ago when the glaciers melted after the last ice age. Without refilling these aquifers there is not much of a future for the region of the United states. As a result ground levels in some areas of the San Joaquin Valley have subsided by more than 30 feet. Similar fossil water depletion is happening in other regions all around the world. TBM and tunneling technology has matured and further developments in the industry are poised to speed up the tunneling process and it's these tunnels that are the only way to move large volumes of water from the ocean inland. The water is moved inland to areas where it can be desalinated in geothermal plants producing clean water and power. In many cases the water will recharge surface reservoirs where it will be used first to make more hydro power before being released into rivers and canal systems. It's very important however to not stop tunneling at these first stops but to continue several legs until the water has traveled from the ocean under mountain ranges to interior states. Along the way water will flow down grade through tunnels and rise in geothermal loops to fill mountain top pumped hydro batteries several times before eventually recharging several major aquifers. What I am proposing is essentially reversing the flow of the Colorado River Compact. Bringing water from the coast of California first to mountaintop reservoirs then to the deserts of Nevada and Arizona and on to Utah, New Mexico, Colorado and Wyoming. This big idea looks past any individual city or states problems and looks at the whole and by using first principles identifies the actual problem and only solution.

There are two long standing problems with doing something about climate change. 
1) the longer we wait to enact meaningful and effective changes the more drastic and potentially economically disruptive those changes have to be - which creates more pressure from opposition and science deniers.
2) There looms various 'tipping points' where Mother Nature takes over and starts expelling gases in a self-perpetuating cycle that humans can't do anything about

I'm fairly certain we've already reached a 'tipping point' of no return. The permafrost is melting at rates 70 years ahead of projections (per CCAG). The pools that are forming are not refreezing. They retain more solar heat; expanding and multiplying; and expelling more gases. As more CO2 and, at least 10x's worse (as a 'greenhouse gas'), methane are released - temps will rise. At a certain temperature and saturation the oceans will begin releasing trapped CO2 as well. From what I've been seeing the past year or so we have lost the ability to mitigate the problem.

A third issue has been that even those who believe in and care about global warming, including myself, do little more than pay lip service and make concerned faces IF the subject comes up. I'll be dead within 20 years or so anyway and have no children or family to worry about - those that do seem oddly indifferent for an animal capable of blushing ...

üÜò (CNN) April 2, 2022¬†In Antarctica the last six months were the coldest on record.
"For the polar darkness period, from April through September, the average temperature was -60.9 degrees Celsius (-77.6 degrees Fahrenheit), a record for those months," the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC) said.
The last six months is also the darkest period at the South Pole, which is where the name polar darkness (also¬†called polar night)comes from. Here, the sun sets for the last time around the spring equinox, and does not rise again until near the autumn equinox six months later.¬†

		
For the entire Antarctic continent, the winter of 2021 was the second-coldest on record, with the "temperature for June, July, and August 3.4 degrees Celsius (6.1 degrees Fahrenheit) lower than the 1981 to 2010 average at -62.9 degrees Celsius (-81.2 degrees Fahrenheit)," according to a¬†new report¬†from the NSIDC. This is incorrect. I'd love to see your sources. An increase in CO2 concentration creates a feedback loop. An example of this is through ocean acidification. The oceans absorb the CO2, making it more acidic, and plankton and other organisms that produce O2 perish due to the acidity. This means less photosynthesis and more atmospheric CO2. Another example is through the melting of ice caps. When the sea levels rise, more land is covered by water. Land surfaces reflect more light than the oceans, and so more sunlight is trapped, creating more heat. There are many more examples of feedback loops.

comment_text:
To limit global warming, rich countries like Canada must end oil and gas production by 2034: report  -----------------
For the world to have a shot at limiting global warming to 1.5 C, Canada and other wealthy fossil fuel producing nations need to stop all production by 2034, according to a new report.

The reduction in greenhouse gas emissions required to secure a livable future is ‚Äúfar more challenging‚Äù than any global leader is prepared to acknowledge, said Kevin Anderson, one of the authors of the report and a professor of energy and climate change at the University of Manchester. Emissions from fossil fuels are one of the main drivers of human-caused climate change.

Published on March 21, the report by the International Institute for Sustainable Development proposes different phaseout dates for oil and gas producing countries by grouping them according to their differing wealth, development and economic reliance on fossil fuels.

It found there isn‚Äôt room for any country in the world to increase fossil fuel production, and wealthy countries like Canada, the U.S. and the U.K. must be the first to end production to give smaller, poorer nations an equitable transition and provide them with financial support. The richest countries, which produce over a third of the world‚Äôs oil and gas, must cut output by 74 per cent by 2030 while the poorest, which supply just one ninth of global demand, must cut back by 14 per cent.

If wealthy countries end fossil fuel production by 2034, middle-income countries by 2043 and the poorest countries by 2050, the world will have a 50 per cent chance of keeping global warming below 1.5 C, according to the report.

‚ÄúWould we be prepared to put our children on a plane with a 50/50 chance they're going to land safely?‚Äù Anderson asked. ‚ÄúI think we probably wouldn't ‚Ä¶ Why is it better to take that risk with their futures?‚Äù

A recent report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) warns that even if countries act urgently and limit global warming to 1.5 C ‚Äî the threshold scientists say is necessary to maintain a livable planet ‚Äî the world will still face ‚Äúunavoidable‚Äù and steadily worsening impacts from climate change over the next two decades.

Canada has had a taste of these impacts with the deadly heat wave, floods and wildfires that plagued B.C. last year. Anderson said people in poor countries are already suffering more severe effects of climate change, and warming beyond 1.5 C is ‚Äúnearly a death sentence.‚Äù

‚ÄúMany people are suffering and dying from climate change a long way from the places that are causing the problems like the E.U., the U.K., Canada, the U.S.,‚Äù he said.

The report found wealthy nations must phase out fossil fuel production well before poorer producing nations for there to be any semblance of an equitable transition.

The authors determined how much economic capacity all the fossil fuel producing countries have by calculating each nation‚Äôs GDP without oil and gas revenues.

Despite being small fossil fuel producers, countries like South Sudan, Congo-Brazzaville and Gabon have little economic revenue apart from oil and gas production, so rapidly removing this income could threaten their political stability and collapse their economies, said Anderson.

‚ÄúFor some parts of the world, oil and gas is like 60-odd per cent of their economy. If you remove that ‚Ä¶ they've almost got nothing left,‚Äù he said.

Wealthy nations like Canada that are major producers, on the other hand, have very diverse economies and typically remain wealthy even once the oil and gas revenue is removed, said Anderson.

For example, the report says Canada‚Äôs GDP would remain the 13th highest globally, even without revenue from oil and gas.

Oil and gas revenues make up 10 per cent of Canada‚Äôs GDP, according to the report, which is ‚Äúnot an insignificant amount, but an amount that's relatively easy for us to replace with other sources,‚Äù said Catherine Abreu, founder of Destination Zero and a member of Canada‚Äôs Net-Zero Advisory Body.

If we ‚Äúkeep up the pretence‚Äù that Canada‚Äôs oil and gas industry is critical for the country‚Äôs economic well-being and it will be ‚Äútoo hard‚Äù to transition, ‚Äúhow can we expect anyone else for whom it is actually much more difficult to do it?‚Äù asked Abreu.

‚ÄúCanada's plans for fossil fuel expansion (are) the second largest in the world ‚Ä¶ So Canada is really one of the worst culprits in putting forward plans for this industry that are really out of step with our commitments in the Paris Agreement.‚Äù

The Canada Energy Regulator says that under the country‚Äôs current policies, Canadian oil production is projected to keep increasing and peak in 2040 before declining slightly, while gas production will steadily increase to 40 per cent above current levels by 2050. It does not include any scenarios compatible with achieving net-zero emissions by 2050 or holding to 1.5 C.

The phaseout dates in the report were calculated by taking stock of the world‚Äôs carbon budget, countries‚Äô total fossil fuel production and their economic ability to phase out coal, oil and gas. Although this method allowed some wiggle room to give poorer countries more time to transition, it is ‚Äústill not fair for poorer countries‚Äù and needs to be paired with ‚Äúbig financial transfers‚Äù from wealthy countries, said Anderson.

‚ÄúOur pathways still (are) unfair on the poorer parts of the world if you look at the total emissions per person over the timeframe that we have,‚Äù he said. The fact that women, children and people of colour are most impacted by climate change points to a broader issue of racism embedded in climate action, or lack thereof, Anderson added, and the institutional racism that exists in the Global North also manifests itself globally.

‚ÄúWe've been highly inequitable to people who have suffered those racial injustices for centuries now and we're just layering another racial injustice on top,‚Äù he said.

The federal government recently announced that $315 million of Canada‚Äôs five-year, $5.3-billion climate finance commitment will be available for organizations in Canada and the Global South to partner on climate adaptation projects, but rich countries ‚Äî including Canada ‚Äî are still falling well short of what is needed.

At the end of the month, the federal government will unveil its emissions reduction plan, which Abreu says is the first step to acknowledging Canada has to tackle oil and gas sector emissions. This report makes it clear we need to be going beyond that first step and account for the emissions from the oil and gas we export, not just production, said Abreu.

The report does not include negative-emissions technologies like carbon capture and storage and nature-based solutions because ‚Äúthey are highly uncertain and speculative, (and) we do not have any examples at scale,‚Äù said Anderson.

‚ÄúIt's dangerous to assume that it will work when it's that uncertain,‚Äù he said, noting the report‚Äôs authors still researched negative-emissions technologies but left them out to avoid increasing the carbon budget without a guarantee it is safe to do so.

‚ÄúWe always ignore the part of the science that tells us actually, the budgets might be much smaller so your policies need to be much more stringent,‚Äù he said.

World leaders are gambling if they continue to use more fossil fuels and don‚Äôt act urgently to phase them out, he added.

‚ÄúWe're playing Russian roulette with our own children's futures,‚Äù said Anderson. ‚ÄúThat's what we're doing, spinning the chamber with one bullet in it and holding it up to our children's head at breakfast and saying, ‚ÄòShall we be lucky?‚Äô‚Äù

Geologist Ro Kinzler.
It turns out that we are most likely in an "ice age" now. So, in fact, the last ice age hasn't ended yet!



Scientists call this ice age the Pleistocene Ice Age. It has been going on since about 2.5 million years ago (and some think that it's actually part of an even longer ice age that started as many as 40 million years ago).
The curious thing about ice ages is that the temperature of Earth's atmosphere doesn't stay cold the entire time. Instead, the climate flip-flops between what scientists call "glacial periods" and "interglacial periods."



Glacial periods last tens of thousands of years. Temperatures are much colder, and ice covers more of the planet.



On the other hand, interglacial periods last only a few thousand years and the climate conditions are similar to those on Earth today. 
We are in an interglacial period right now. It began at the end of the last glacial period, about 10,000 years ago.





Scientists are still working to understand what causes ice ages. One important factor is the amount of light Earth receives from the Sun. The amount of sunlight that reaches Earth can vary quite a lot, mainly due to three factors:
 how much Earth is tilted relative to the Sun whether Earth wobbles a lot or a little as it spins on its axis 
(kind of like how a toy top can wobble a lot or a little as it spins) the shape of Earth's orbit as it goes around the Sun (whether it is shaped more like a circle or more like an ellipse or oval)

Over thousands of years, the amount of sunshine reaching Earth changes by quite a lot, particularly in the northern latitudes, the area near and around the North Pole. When less sunlight reaches the northern latitudes, temperatures drop and more water freezes into ice, starting an ice age. When more sunlight reaches the northern latitudes, temperatures rise, ice sheets melt, and the ice age ends. But there are many other factors. So if you became a climate scientist one day, you could make your own discoveries!



To find out more about Earth's climate in the past, scientists study ice cores. These samples tell us that during the current ice age, climate on Earth has flip-flopped between glacial and interglacial periods at least 17 times!
So it is very likely that Earth will turn cold again, possibly within the next several thousand years. But, we have to keep in mind that human activities today are impacting climate on a global scale. So when we predict future climate changes, including the next glacial period, we need to consider the changes that humans are causing.



Keep on asking questions! There's still much we don't know about the past and future of our planet.

Tuvalu is GROWING sport !, think how things were only 5000 years ago when sea level was 1-2 m HIGHER than NOW !
Only 4500 years ago there was a significant drop in sea level, we have yet to regain those natural levels !
Most Pacific islands are GROWING !, coral atolls are formed by SINKING volcanic mountains as they move off the oceanic crust bulged by a hot spot , as those volcanoes sink under the ocean their surrounding reefs continue to grow and this creates Atolls, as long as coral growth  keeps up with or exceeds the rate of sinking then the Atoll survives or grows.
The stories you seem to have read in the media about this are as usual factually untrue in most cases.
Sea levels fluctuate over the 115000 year cycle of glaciation and interglacial, they rose by 130 METERS at the onset of the current interglacial, but have risen  AND fallen  over the last 11000 years.
If you make your home on the remnants of a sinking mountain  covered in coral, you always live a precarious existence, just have a look at the Emperor seamounts they are the sunken remains of the first Hawaiian islands  the same is true of the Galapagos, no one knows if the Pacific Atolls will continue to grow though its likely, or if natural sea level rise will overwhelm them in time.
One thing is certain there is NO indication that burning of fossil fuels has increased the rate of sea level rise at all.

"Climate change" is not a re-branding of "global warming": It refers to the broader range of phenomena cause by man-made global warming, including changing seasons, intensifying droughts and wildfires, more extreme precipitation when the skies do open up, changing precipitation due to more days being above freezing, other changes in precipitation due to disruption of the jet stream and water cycle due to man-made global warming, hurricanes intensifying more rapidly, traveling slower, and degrading more slowly over land, etc. 

Personally, I prefer "man-made global warming and climate disruption."

Sea level rise isn't even across the planet. It's falling close to melting ice sheets, due to reduced ice mass reducing gravitational pull towards the sheets. And changes in wind patterns, ocean salinity and ocean currents - e g. the gulf stream is slowing down causing rapid SL rise along US east coast. If the gulf stream (amoc) stops altogether then sea level will rise about 1m along the US east coast and that's on top of any general global increase.

You really have NO IDEA about the relevant science do you ?
The poles are both within NORMAL variability , both the Antarctic AND Greenland are cooling
overall the Antarctic for 35 years now .
There has been NO overall global increase for some years now, the land surface temp in the U.S has not warmed overall since 2005, and as that system was set up in 2005, we have to look at other data before that, the onset of the pause was in 1998.
Tokyo has NOT warmed overall for decades and a Japanese island had NOT warmed overall for 71 years !
Our fossil fuels are likely adding some warming to the natural warming we are in but as Co2 has NEVER been a major forcing on global temperature that is not likely to be much.
Remember the MORE atmospheric Co2 the LESS additional warming you get, its effect is logarithmic NOT linear, so you can double Co2 without much temperature increase, its greatest warming effect is at 20 ppm, with every doubling after that the additional warming is smaller and smaller.
The paleoclimate data is clear its warming temperatures that drive up atmospheric Co2 levels with a lag of 800-1000 years (how long ago was the medieval Warm Period ?), higher co2 levels NEVER prevent subsequent cooling !, in fact Co2 continues to rise for some time after temperatures fall overall.
You can see that with the onset of the short term cooling phase in 1940 that ran for 37 years till 1977, WW2 pushed up Co2 emissions but temperature fell as it does, before warming again after 1977.
That cooling phase followed the previous warming phase which peaked in the late 1930's 
(and still holds the records for the longest period of hot weather and the highest number of broken high temperature records in the U.S), the long term temperature record is one long series of warmings and coolings over a variety of time cycles running simultaneously.
Remember the Medieval warm period was at least as warm as now and probably warmer, the Roman warm period as warmer still, the Minoan warming was warmer again and the Holocene Thermal Optimum was as hot as its been in the current interglacial, (though the previous two interglacials were both significantly warmer than ours has been).
Overall the peak warmings have  been getting shorter and cooler over the last 11000 years as we move back into the next glacial over the next few thousand years.
There is NOTHING about our current temperatures, weather OR climate that is in any way unusual, all are TOTALLY within normal long term variability.
That is the current reality, attempts by the IPCC modellers to predict the future have been thirty years of failure !
The only accurate way to view this is to look at what has really happened and leave fortune telling to carnivals.
As always every single prediction of disaster has NEVER HAPPENED.

@Hahn Ilso "we are entering an interstadal glacial period. Like all others it will last at least 20,000 years." You are talking about how the cycles worked before we increased global CO2 levels--which changes everything. We are driving global temps and all the feedback loops away from an ice age. Human activity is now the main force shaping the future of life on Earth. /

"Carbon has exclusively followed warming and cooling trends on the planet by 300 years and it has been like this for millions of years." That's oversimplifying Earth's history AND how temps, CO2, and water vapor interact. First, at some points in earth's history, there were massive releases of CO2 which drove warming. Second, the relationship is reciprocal and bi-directional: Whichever you increase first will increase the other. If you increases temps first (as orbital cycles have done), that inevitably triggers more CO2, which triggers more water vapor, which triggers still more CO2 release, more warming, more water vapor, and so on. Thus, a great deal of the eventual warming in past warming periods was actually due to the release of CO2, even if some initial warming was triggered first.

Third, we know this time around, our release of massive amounts of CO2 is what caused the warming. Natural drivers account for a whopping net ZERO warming from 1880-2020: ALL of it is accounted for by our release of greenhouse gases, deforestation and tilling (which alter the carbon cycle) and the amplification effects of more water vapor caused by the evaporation caused by the original warming caused by more CO2. 

Sorry, we know we caused it this time around.

@peter jones Yes, Peter, I know it's a log scale. I'm a researcher, and I've studied this issue and how people get fooled about it for years. But here's the problem, while 300 ppm of CO2 provides over 50 degrees F of warming, the tiny bit of additional warming from rapidly raising CO2 levels further is still lethal to life. A few degrees C warmer, and much of the fat middle of the Earth becomes uninhabitable for humans without AC and unable to support our crops in the former breadbaskets of the world. 

"This is why Co2 levels greater than 4000 ppm  have NEVER resulted in catastrophic global warming, "Actually, five times in Earth's history, rapid spikes in CO2 were followed by mass die offs of life. 

"in fact if you averaged Co2 levels over the history of life you would get around 1500 ppm, which is the level most plants prefer." That's an irrelevant data point. Most life that has existed on Earth is dead and. gone, and the species that are here NOW are well-adapted to CO2 levels of 300 ppm or lower. Furthermore, we located our cities and farms and built our civilization around a climate based on much lower CO2 levels. But we have already raised CO2 levels enough that unless we stop emitting CO2 and pull lots out of the air, we have locked in ~20 feet of eventual sea level rise. That screws up coastal cities and ports all over the world, and adapting to just that one change would cost tens of trillions of dollars. Far beyond that, due to man-made global warming and climate disruption, Earth's ecosystems either already collapsed, are in the process of breakdown, or are heading for collapse. The Earth has been in a global browning trend for 20 years due to the hotter and drier conditions we created. 

"I myself have been watching failed predictions of climate catastrophe from the same organizations and some of the same scientists for 44 years." And as a researcher, I have studied how people like you have gotten fooled by cherry-picked failed predictions from non-experts (or misinterpreted predictions). In fact, if you actually look at what the majority of experts in various fields predicted... all the major predictions of the theory of man-made global warming have come true, 14 different climate models, some dating back to the 1970s and 80s, have quite accurately predicted how much warming our emissions would cause, and global ice melt, sea level rise, and ecosystem breakdown are not only accelerating, they are happening faster than predictions from back in the 1990s. I can provide more details if you wish.

Take care.

@Richard Webb Nothing funny about it: Dinosaurs lived during the Mesozoic era, 65-245 million years ago. The Cambrian period, which you were stressing, was 485-541 million years ago, so it ended 240 MILLION YEARS before the era of the dinosaurs started. 

Here's the problem that most people don't understand: WE are not dinosaurs and we and all the other living things on Earth have been adapted to much cooler temps and much lower CO2 levels, so if you suddenly crank up the CO2 levels and temps to Mesozoic levels, most current life on Earth would simply go extinct. Talking about how high CO2 levels were hundreds of millions of years ago when entirely different species roamed the Earth is a waste of time, but it is used to confuse people about the issues. 

I'm a veteran researcher, I've studied these issues for more than a decade: If we don't stop burning fossil fuels, stop destroying ecosystems, and stop polluting the planet, we are heading for a mass extinction event... and the early stages of the collapse have already begun... we've killed off half the corals reefs and 60% of the wild animals that lived as recently as the 1970s, and due to the hotter and drier conditions we have created, the Earth has been tipped into a "global browning" phase in which more and more plants and forests are drying up and dying. But those living things are what makes our lives possible. 

Take care.

@Richard Webb "go back, read my comment with a little comprehension.
The hotter planet, during Cambrian period, had higher Co2, whilst having MORE DIVERSITY OF LIFE. Richard, I hate to break this to you, but there was no life on land during the Cambrian period--no plants, no animals, nada. The land was hot dry, and desolate, like a Mad Max movie, but without the cars, people, or even dead trees. OK, maybe more like Dune. 

It's infuriating that all those climate denier channels that make a big deal out of the Cambrian seem to suspiciously leave out that critical fact.   

"colder temperatures PREVENT DIVERSITY OF LIFE! Got it now?"

The diversity of life on earth now is perhaps as great as it has ever been AND we evolved in cooler conditions with lower CO2 levels. We're not dinosaurs, so it doesn't matter what conditions were even then, because all life on Earth has been adapted to cooler temps and lower CO2 levels for a couple million years, and if you rapidly change the Earth's conditions, things go extinct. The last time the Earth warmed this rapidly and oceans acidified this rapidly, 95% of marine life went extinct as did 70% of life on land, including everything over 90 pounds. Species can adapt if you change conditions very slowly over thousands or millions of years, but if you rapidly disrupt their habitats, they go extinct: Due to man-made global warming, ecosystem destruction, direct killing of species and chemical and plastic pollution, we are already racing down the on-ramp to the sixth mass extinction of life on earth. 

We can change course and save most of the millions of species on Earth, but it requires decarbonizing our economy and shrinking consumption in wealthy countries to fit within the limits of what the Earth can provide and withstand.

I know what you are angling at. But before I say I must add that I am aware that in the past life has endured much higher levels of CO2 equivalent challenges. However, there has been a gradual descent of CO2 concentrations and corresponding global mean temperatures beginning 50 million years ago at the Cenozoic thermal maximum when terrestrial life endured much higher temperatures by habitating the higher latitudes. Much of the oceans may have still have not yet recovered from the devastating effects of the PETM.

There were two short-lived interruptions, one of which was likely a result of flood volcanism. It provided a mile thick lava cap on the geology of Eastern Washington, parts of Idaho and parts of Northern Oregon associated with the Columbia River basin. Geologically this is considered to be a minor large igneous province or deep mantle plume volcanism. There was quite a bit of thawing at both poles. 

However, ultimately 2.6 million years ago we entered into the ice age described as the Quaternary which we are currently disrupting and departing from. In contrast to Earth's geologic history during which there have been much warmer periods, even as we have cycled between glaciations and interglacials, we have enjoyed a very mild climate that has fostered abundant and diverse ecosystems both on land and in water. 

With the very abrupt changes that are now occurring this abundance is working against us. On land, more and more it's biomass is entering the domain of Fire. In water, beyond the effects of overfishing, acidification, eutrophication with subsequent hypoxia, anoxia, and euxenia, along with warming are ravaging ecosystem complexity as well as driving some of the mobile towards the poles. 

Also, under rather thin subsea permafrost perched on the shallow Arctic Ocean's shelves there are large catches of methane contained in temperature stabilized hydrates, aka clathrates, that have likely been accumulating at least during the last 800,000 years since we had transitioned into 100,000 year glaciation cycles.

Increasing insolation absorbing open Arctic Ocean water is a very large threat in consideration of the above described situation and large releases of methane there will be much more impactful than normal. Hydroxyl radicals that low temperature oxidize methane into CO2 and H2O form from the photolysis of water vapor in the upper troposphere. There is much less water vapor in the colder Arctic atmosphere. With rapid releases a methane in the Arctic higher concentrations will subsequently there localize to the extent that it's CO2 equivalent forcing value will be 150 to 200 times that of CO2 rather than the normal quoted value of 86 times over two decades. Thus feeding back on itself visions of the fabled clathrate gun nightmare begin to appear.

We could tolerate much warmer temperatures by shifting towards the poles. However, currently the dynamic is going to be very challenging for all of life currently residing on Earth.

This is an important message. But I think it's important to note that it doesn't stop getting worse at 3 degrees. If we do fail to prevent a rise of 3 degrees, we may still have a chance to prevent a rise of 4 degrees. And if we can't prevent a rise of 4 degrees, perhaps we can prevent a rise of 5 degrees. It keeps getting worse, ad infinitum, until we either solve this, or we start reaching levels where human extinction becomes a real possibility (my guess is that's around the 10 degree mark, based on what I've learned about the Permian extinction). The flip side of that is that no matter how bad it gets, it's always possible to prevent it from getting even worse, so don't give up if we fail to meet one goal (in fact IIRC stopping a 3 degree rise is already our second goalpost, since I remember a few years ago we were talking about trying to prevent a rise of 2 degrees).

Disappointing. The two big complaints are due to their focus on the direct impacts from the environment over the next eighty years.

First, they miss the feedback loops that the gradually escalating interim crises will create. As rich countries are called upon for aid by their citizens, they'll be less likely to help poorer countries (witness the lack of COVID vaccines going to the poorest countries), or even cooperate with other wealthy countries (beyond lip service ‚Äî already evident at climate summits). The economic disruption will accelerate as the climate crisis becomes more and more evident, reducing the likelihood that anything ever gets done.

Second, by pointing to the 3¬∞C increase at the end of the century, they make it easy for people to treat this like a horror story that will maybe happen to strangers. ‚ÄúThat's a long time from now, surely someone will fix the problem well before then.‚Äù They should be pointing to the unprecedented flooding in Germany, the unprecedented heat wave in Australia, the melting of permafrost in Alaska and Siberia, the fires in the U.S. west ‚Äî all happening now, and all harbingers of worse to come. People need to be scared about their own futures, not that of their grandchildren's.

Why only 3 degrees higher? Why not 5 - 8 degrees. The later was the reality of the 'Paleocene-Eocene' Thermal Maximum' period that began around 56 million years ago.  Like the period before it there was no icecaps but with even higher temperatures and CO2 levels. Did the world shrivel up under the blistering heat? No, the fossil record shows it was covered in tropical rain forest and supported the development of early mammals including our primate ancestors. So instead of images of parched desserts, imagine sitting on the treetops looking out over a luxuriant green canopy or bathing in the warm waters of the arctic circle. If there ever was a 'Garden of Eden' that led to the eventual establishment of man this was it.  If you are still not convinced you only have to go back to the warmer periods in the Roman and Medieval times. The later witnessed Southern England with a climate akin to the Loire valley today and Greenland being more habitable than present (encouraging a brief Viking settlement). Let us not also forget the remains of vast forests that lie under Northern Tundra revealing a time of warmer weather that made more of the world more habitable.

@Jason Stevenson "Technology can allow us to maintain our diets and still do as you ask." Human agriculture currently take over 10 billion acres of Earth's land. Replace the beef and lamb/mutton in our diets and overnight we suddenly we only need 5 billion acres to feed everyone and could reforest or re-wild the rest, thus restoring biodiversity and sequestering hundreds of billions of tons of carbon. What technology do you have that can match that--AND whose mining, transport of raw materials, manufacture, transport of finished product, lifespan of product, and disposal of product doesn't harm Earth's ecosystems even more?

@Karl Wheatley Sorry but I am not going to become vegetarian and neither will most people on the planet. Technology can allow us to maintain our diets and still do as you ask. 

"The bottom line is that industrialized consumerist capitalism  is flatly incompatible with the limits and laws of nature"

That isn't the bottom  line. The bottom line is we don't yet have the technology. For example, consumerism in France isn't a problem because France generates 80% of its electricity from emissions free nuclear energy. 

Plant-rich diets ? Give up now because that isn't going to happen.
Passive homes, walkable cities - really? How many of the nearly 8 billion people in the planet can walk to work or walk to shopping? And how about aircraft, ships?

A circular economy, educating goals, reducing food waste, reforestation? Some of this is great but are minor very issues relative to the dispatchable energy equation. 
Greater economic equality? How is that going to help? Socialism worked great for the Soviet Unions environment.

"Hundreds of other strategies certainly WILL stop what I'm worried about" They will not certainly stop anything. Based upon the examples you have provided and the world's actions to date I have no confidence whatsoever.

@Jason Stevenson "Yet again you are avoiding the point." Then maybe state whatever you think "the point" is more clearly.  

"If the technology was adequate we would not be having this discussion." That's not how humans work. We are not fully rational, long-term thinking, benefit-maximizing organisms. Economics and psychological research disproved that long-ago. We are partially rational beings and our politics is wrapped up in power. There are LOTS of things that would make sense to do and 60-70% of the population wants government to do but they don't happen because the whims of billionaires and giant corporations have far more control than they should. 

"Governments set the regulatory framework that CEO and oil companies must work within." Yes, and governments and political parties in the US and elsewhere got hijacked by the profit motive and neoliberal fictions starting 40 years ago during the Reagan/Thatcher revolutions. Let me be clear, I'm not standing on a soapbox yelling at CEOs--they are just puppets in a dysfunctional system doing the role they are paid to do. Sure, I'm mad about what they are doing, but whining about specific CEOs is just rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic. 

The bottom line is that industrialized consumerist capitalism  is flatly incompatible with the limits and laws of nature. Either we replace it with a non-growing and vastly more eco-friendly private sector economy or we are heading toward the collapse of ecosystems and human civilization, whether we decarbonize or not. 

So if your "main point" is that we don't have enough solar and wind and geothermal to keep "biggering" our economy, that would be a critical strength not weakness of renewables. 

"Wind, solar and batteries will never stop what you are warning of." Not sure what you think I mean, but renewable energy along with plant-rich diets, passive homes, walkable cities, a circular economy, educating goals, reducing food waste, reforestation, greater economic equality, great mass transit, walkable cities, and hundreds of other strategies certainly WILL stop what I'm worried about. 

Take care

Carbon emissions haven't trended downward since the start of the industrial revolution. Country by country metrics don't matter as long as global emissions still trend upwards - all countries share the same atmosphere. And you're right, in a sense, that population has a role but that's because consumer goods, methane intensive food and other essentials for life in a modern society, have to be produced at a higher frequency to match the growing population. The real "Elephant in the room" is how we produce commodities and how we produce energy. Converting coal fire power plants to solar, wind or even nuclear would be a monumental step in reducing climate change, that wouldn't result in just culling people or desterrilising them ... lol

Global population growth is only a small part of the problem. We could hover at around the same global population and we would still be decimated by climate change. The real problem is how we produce commodities and how we generate electricity. These 2 things - intense industry and coal fired power plants - drive the problem of climate change. For example, meat production is responsible for 15% of global man-made climate change. We could entirely eliminate this and rely on meat substitutes or make a push for vegetarianism. No de-population needed. 25% of global man made emissions are from electricity and heat production, so switch to renewables and create more efficient heating mechanisms. No de-population needed and we're almost halfway there! The economic incentive of oil, gas, meat production, and all fossil fuels needs to be removed if we want to survive as a species - de-population or not.

1200ppm CO2 will be reached, which will see a dramatic increase in plant growth and vegetation density. Fauna will follow flora. Temperatures  on the equator will be only about 2  Kelvin higher, While desert belts will be moved to slightly higher latitudes.
No one really believes that energy consumption will stall or even decrease. Economists know this would lead to large scale wars. So if the models are correct this scenario has a bigger than 90% chance to play out. Adaptation is the way that all life goes when climate changes happen. Adaptation is about 90% more effective than mitigation, while resistance leads to extinction , and is the least  (or most) effective depending on the perspective. This is where businesses show their agility. They quickly adapt and everything becomes green and clean, and sustainable, Adaptation is the secret of evolution and the most energy efficient response to climate change. As humans change the planet, the consequence is that they have to adapt.And as humans are very adaptive, most futurists predict a bright, even if slightly warmer future for our civilization. One thing is clear, panic never improved the odds of survival. So we must at least keep our heads cool and adapt. The gap of poor and rich was never a climate issue. It was and will always be a competition issue, a pure free market concept that nature invented to drive evolution. Over sufficiently long periods of time there are no winners and losers. In a couple of hundred years Europe could be a basket case, while Africa is Utopia. Of course, this is not to justify complacency in the face of stark inequalities, but it is a view beyond  human life spans on par with climate changes which always were a main driver of civilizatory evolution. So it all comes down to how much and how quickly we have to adapt. A generational cycle is natural, a higher adaptation rate will cause extra stress. However, with the current measures taken, there will be no catastrophic stress. That would occur with a planet killer asteroid appearing 5 years out from Earth, or the collapse of Earth‚Äòs magnet field. With cool heads and our given intelligence we will learn and adapt and of course survive. We should not spread fear and depression but confidence and optimism, in particular those who have sufficient knowledge on this matter.

The Climate Waits for No One
Thirty years ago, a friend of mine got into the green energy business and tried to pull me into it. I asked him what for, it isn‚Äôt serious. He said, ‚ÄúYou have no idea how much money is being poured into it. Everyone wants in on it, politicians, financiers, businesspeople, the lot.‚Äù He was right, of course. Yet, no one wants to promote green energy in order to save the planet, but only to swell up their pockets even more. The declarations, therefore, remain in the assembly hall where they are stated, necessary actions are ignored, and the climate waits for no one: It will keep deteriorating.
This week in Glasgow, Scotland, the 26th UN Climate Change Conference is taking place. Officially, it aims to ‚Äúbring parties together to accelerate action towards the goals of the Paris Agreement and the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change.‚Äù In reality, the countries plan to do the exact opposite. This year‚Äôs UN Production Gap Report, which tracks the discrepancy between governments‚Äô planned fossil fuel production and actual global production levels, states the following: ‚ÄúDespite increased climate ambitions and net-zero commitments, governments still plan to produce more than double the amount of fossil fuels in 2030 than what would be consistent with limiting global warming to 1.5¬∞C [2.7¬∞F].‚Äù
Energy sources and technologies do change, but not according to what is best for the planet. It changes according to the interests of politicians and money moguls, and it never benefits the planet or the majority of its inhabitants, namely all of us.
Since the climate waits for no one, eventually, it will catch up with us. Earth is a closed system, and in a closed system, there are consequences to exploitation: it hurts the abuser as well as the abused.
I don‚Äôt know when or at what cost, but eventually, we will all have to realize that we cannot take beyond what we need. We cannot keep exploiting Earth selfishly and thoughtlessly because it will turn against us.
Earth is like a submarine: there is only so much oxygen on board. If some crew members take more than their quota, the rest will not have enough, they will die, and the submarine will sink along with those who exceeded their quota.
We need constant reminders that we are one system, and we are all dependent on each other. We need to genuinely grasp that selfishness hurts us just as being exploitative hurts others. If we constantly remind ourselves that we are interdependent, we will behave with more consideration, and we will avoid the punitive impact of climate change.
The other option is to keep working as the UN‚Äôs Production Gap Report states that we are planning to work, and suffer nature‚Äôs unforgiving response. I hope we wise up in time because everyone will pay the price for this mistake.

According to well understood physical parameters, the effectiveness of CO2 as a greenhouse gas diminishes logarithmically with increasing concentration and from the current level of ~390 ppmv, (parts per million by volume). Accordingly only ~5% of the effectiveness of CO2 as a greenhouse gas remains beyond the current level.This inconvenient fact is well understood in the climate science community. It can be accurately modeled using the Modtran program maintained and supported at the University of Chicago.The logarithmic diminution of the effect of CO2 is probably the reason why there was no runaway greenhouse warming from CO2 in earlier eons when CO2 levels were known to be at levels of several thousands ppmv.Remarkably, IPCC Published reports , (TAR3), do actually acknowledge that the effective temperature increase caused by growing concentrations of CO2 in the atmosphere radically diminishes with increasing concentrations. This information is in their report. It is well disguised for any lay reader, (Chapter 6. Radiative Forcing of Climate Change: section 6.3.4 Total Well-Mixed Greenhouse Gas Forcing Estimate).Although the IPCC tacitly acknowledges that this crucial diminution effect with increasing concentrations effect exists, it certainly does not go out of its way to emphasise it. Like the Medieval Warm Period, that they attempted to eliminate with the Hockey Stick graph in 2001, the panel knows that wide public knowledge of the diminution effect with increasing CO2 concentration would be utterly detrimental to their primary message.From the present concentration of atmospheric CO2 at approaching 400 ppmv, only ~5% of the effectiveness of CO2 as a Greenhouse Gas remains. This can only give rise to a maximum of a further of ~+0.21¬∞C. Thereafter beyond 1000+ ppmv the effect of increasing levels of CO2 can only ever be absolutely minimal even if CO2 concentrations were to increase indefinitely.

I know, it's what is called, the Water Vapour Positive Feedback Loop. This theory suggests that CO2's greenhouse effect will warm the atmosphere and, hence, the oceans; which will create more water vapour; which will cause the atmosphere and, thus, the oceans to warm even more, releasing yet more CO2; and so on, one feeding upon the other. However, that isn't happening! It hasn't happened because, firstly, CO2's greenhouse effect has maxed out and, secondly, we now know that extra water vapour doesn't gather in the upper troposphere in the tropical latitudes, it simply condenses and falls as rain. That is not a theory, that is an observed fact. As I'm sure you know, nature doesn't like a positive feedback. Unless, and until, we can grow Barley in Greenland the way the Vikings did it for 400 years between 1000 to 1400 A.D., videos like this was are absolutely baseless and devoid of all credibility.  Growing Barley requires 100 frost free days, and the Vikings wouldn't live where they couldn't make Meade, their favorite alcoholic beverage.  That requires Honey,  so they had Honeybees in Greenland.  Those Viking farms have long since been abandoned, they sit under 5 feet of snow in modern day summer.  In order to do all of that, the average annual temperature of Greenland would have had to be between 6 to 8 degrees Celsius higher than today, and here this video is taking about 3 degrees?  Sorry, but there is no correlation between CO2 and temperature, and even the IPCC admits to only 1.07 degrees warming in the last 150 years.  The temperature forcing factor of CO2 is logarithmic and not linear.  That means total atmospheric CO2 would have to double to produce 1 degree of heat, and double again for each additional degree.  We simply do not have sufficient 'fossil fuels' to get there, no matter how desirable a warmer world would be, and life always thrives when the world is warmer.  Life suffers when it gets colder. Climate is currently warming uncontrollably due to human-caused greenhouse gas emissions since industrialization.  It may already be running away to some unknown level where it will finally stop warming, but that could be no ice on the planet, including permafrost.

Earth's climate hasn't been this hot since 125,000 years ago. Yup, you can almost smell methane going up in the air up there with permafrost thawing. Funny thing, no one knows yet to what extent permafrost is affected. More than half the total amount of terrestrial carbon sits in those once eternally frozen areas. But it's not been included in IPCC reports until the latest one, and they still have no beginning of a clue of what the actual situation is. Hardly any measurements, no working monitoring system yet in place, only some preliminary satellite data and estimates. 
Methane comes from decomposition of organic matter in thawed permafrost, only last a decade or so in free air, _but_ is 30 times more powerful greenhouse gas than CO2. Large amounts emitted over several decades can hike up global temp up to half a degree, if permafrost goes in long time degradation. Chances are it will, with those higher temps in the Arctic.
When did records start?

While the methane question is one that could potentially have already determined the planet's approximate end point, we do not know for sure, and we also do not know if the temperature alone has passed a tipping point.  There is a form of denial that has begun to crop up that some climate scientists like Dr. Michael Mann call "inactivism" which tries to play up doomsday fears in order to retain the status quo.  Now, you may genuinely believe this, not just using this as a status quo argument, but Dr. Mann indicates well-intentioned people can fall into the inactivism trap.

While the situation humanity finds itself in is precarious, we don't know for sure it is out of our control yet, unknown if the runaway train is faster than we can catch to slow down.  It is the most rational course of action to do all we can regarding mitigation while preparing for some of the more unthinkable possibilities as well.

Even some climate experts are in denial that we've reached or passed the tipping point, and feedbacks like you mention will just runaway with climate until some unknown mechanism puts it in a new equilibrium. There are simply too many of us primates on this planet.  By our numbers it's pretty clear that we are an example of an architype Mother Nature dearly loves.  Herds.  From the age of the dinosaurs to todays fish in the seas, birds in the air and past buffalo, elephants and the like it appears she favors large masses, agglomerations,  of biological entities.  

So humanity is her latest experiment in the architype.  This time she's created an intelligent herd.  

But as bright as we are, as intelligent as we appear to be, in a group context we don't seem especially wise.  In a group setting we are the exact opposite of those past herds who accepted and lived within the constraints of their environment.  

In fact we seem prone to irrational acts of folly.  Stupidity, self-interest, avarice and greed, is our norm in large groups.  A not especially evolutionarily attractive trait in a species.  So the experiment, overall, seems now to be in jeopardy.

It comes to this.  We either learn to control ourselves and our numbers, acknowledging that as big as this planet is it is, in fact, a Terrarium.  A closed loop dynamic system with limits.  We either understand this and begin to comport ourselves along those informed lines, or Mother Nature will do it for us.  

Given her tendency she will not care how much we scream about what she does.  Our sensibilities aren't hers.  She will reduce our numbers for us.  

But for now we still have the choice.  We have the option for self-control.  We can reign ourselves in.  Or not.

So choose wisely my primate friends.  Choose wisely.  The future awaits what we do today.

@Jc Mostly the oceans.
Next to carbonate rock deposits, the oceans are the largest Co2 sink.
As the upper ocean levels warm they cannot hold as much Co2 in solution and so its outgassed into the atmosphere.
Its a bit like water vapor in the atmosphere as temperatures cool water condenses out because the atmosphere cant hold it, you can pump more water into the atmosphere but it remains vapor and is condensing as mist.
This is why Co2 levels continue to rise after temperature has cooled, the oceans hold heat longer than the atmosphere.
Thats not to say it accumulates in the atmosphere the turnover of Co2 is ten years or less based on 1960's USAF nuclear air sampling programmes, 
so its being outgassed and reabsorbed but the outgassing exceeds the re absorbtion overall.
The Co2 lag is thought to be from ocean turnover , its likely that some of our Co2 rise is from the Medieval warming.
Higher Co2 levels in the atmosphere NEVER prevent subsequent cooling.
Remember the more Co2 in the atmosphere the LESS additional warming it produces and that effect is logarithmic NOT linear.
Co2 produces its greatest warming effect at 20 ppm with every doubling of Co2 levels the warming is smaller and smaller, at 415 ppm you could double the concentration without significant warming.
We have had massive ice ages on the planet with 4000 ppm + Co2 and high temperatures with very low Co2 levels.
The paleoclimate data shows that Co2 levels have VERY POOR correlation with temperature cycles but solar variability has VERY HIGH correlation with the temperature cycles.
Russian and Finnish and U.K studies indicate the ECS is ACTUALLY .24 deg C at current Co2 levels, the human contribution to that is .01-.02 Deg C.
Its not what i think the paleoclimate data is quite clear.
Human Co2 emissions are LESS than 4% of the annual Co2 output, the vast majority of the Co2 rise in the atmosphere has come from the oceans.
The other sources are rather minor compared to the ocean.
By the way current estimates of past Co2 levels are taken from ice cores, while they provide a useful continuity they are only ESTIMATES of AVERAGES over time usually thousands of years, this removes the peaks and troughs from the record, additionally Russian research indicated Co2 leaches from ice under pressure, so the ice core samples are of limited usefulness in determining spot levels of maximum Co2 at any time.
We do have a few very accurate Co2 spot levels from the last 11000 years in the form of fossil leaf stomata counts , we have counts from the Holocene showing minimum levels of 500 ppm.
This NEVER seems to be ever mentioned, certainly not in the IPCC scientific reports.
Hope that helps.

When it comes to climate models, there are two major problems: not only do they not take ancient climate into consideration (such as previous post-ice age climate) or sun spot activity (the sun effectively being the massive nuclear radiator in the sky heating up everything in the solar system), but the scientists using them have gone into this field because they want to do something about climate change. They have a pre-existing idea of what the climate models should show, which means that as soon as their models show something different they assume there's something wrong with the modelsthemselves and will therefor change the parameters accordingly until they show what said sicentists think they should show. Bias has completely destroyed the entire field of mainstream climate research.

Ireland was traditionally a forest of deciduous hardwoods. Oak, Ash and sycamore and elm as such like trees. Now most of our forestry is Sitka spruce, fast growing and profitable in 20 years as opposed to 40-50 years for hardwoods. A multigenerational finance system is needed at government level to pay forestry workers a wage now for hardwoods which might take 50 years to give a return. This cannot be done at family level like other farm enterprises such as animal or crop production. 
Our forestry companies using spruce and such softwoods cause environmental damage because when the forests are cleared this results in rapid water release in heavy rain storms, deciduous hold onto water runoff for longer and have better support for native wildlife and are better for the environment.
The solution to this problem will take a long time due to divisive interests and short-term financial thinking among a lot of the stakeholders concerned.

@John Russell I experienced the same in Michigan.  Here's how I now think about it.  We as a species settled in northern latitudes where bouts of a particular kind of extreme weather were more or less expected and could be adapted to and tolerated.  We planted crops where food production remained viable in spite of the weather hiccups.  The cold winters kept certain kinds of pests at bay (e.g., pine bark beetles).  And so on.

Global heating is causing us to have to tolerate different kinds of extreme weather.  Now our crops have to deal with the change of seasons coming at different times than before.  They must tolerate floods or droughts during the growing season, instead of cold snaps during the dormant season.  They must tolerate different pests-- ones that thrive in a generally warmer climate.

So ... what does all this change imply for the future?  I believe that if global heating continues apace the new extremes will become even more extreme.  For example, warmer air can hold more moisture, so a warmer rainstorm can drop more water and floods can become worse.  A point might be reached where worsening heat waves become intolerable and people have to migrate away from places like the Middle East, where living conditions are already marginal.  Prolonged droughts or too-frequent flooding could make food production untenable in a particular region and people will have to migrate away.  This is already happening in certain South American regions.

In other words, I think what we have experienced in our lifetimes can legitimately be seen as a warning signal.  We don't want global average temperatures to keep going up.  Our climate will become more unstable and weather extremes could continue to worsen.

Yes, when I was a kid in the 1960s we had extreme weather‚Äîheavy snow that brought everything to a standstill, including school, for days. Today we hardly see snow in winter but instead we have extreme rain leading to flooding. The difference is called, unsurprisingly, 'climate change'.

Lots of scientist are talking about it, one of the more vocal ones are prof Tim Garrett & co with their "growth as a symptom" hypothesis. They treat civilization like a ‚Äúheat engine‚Äù that ‚Äúconsumes energy and does 'work' in the form of economic production, which then spurs it to consume more energy.‚Äù Their study came to two surprising conclusions. First, although improving efficiency through innovation is a hallmark of efforts to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions, efficiency has the side effect of making it easier for civilization to grow and consume more. Second, that the current rates of world population growth may not be the cause of rising rates of energy consumption, but a symptom of past efficiency gains.

"Advocates of energy efficiency for climate change mitigation may seem to have a reasonable point," Garrett says, "but their argument only works if civilization maintains a fixed size, which it doesn't. Instead, an efficient civilization is able to grow faster. It can more effectively use available energy resources to make more of everything, including people. Expansion of civilization accelerates rather than declines, and so do its energy demands and CO2 emissions."

@aaa aa The answer to that question is way beyond my paygrade.  Just like the question: "What total population is optimal for humankind?"  We don't know what's optimal, but we do know with some assurance that the conditions we have at present constitute ecological overshoot.  That is, we have exceeded the sustainable carrying capacity of planet Earth.  How do we know?  By the fact that many aspects of the biosphere that we depend on are, by actual measurement, either being depleted (e.g., aquifers, sea life, soil) or overloaded with waste products (e.g., CO2, fertilizers) at rates faster than nature can restore.
